{{unreferenced|date=November 2009}} The '''Waldorf Statement''' was a two-page press release issued on December 3, 1947, by [[Eric Johnston]], president of the [[Motion Picture Association of America]], following a closed-door meeting by forty-eight [[motion picture]] company executives at [[New York City|New York City's]] [[Waldorf-Astoria Hotel]]. The Statement was a response to the [[contempt of Congress]] charges against the so-called "[[Hollywood blacklist#The Hollywood Ten|Hollywood Ten]]".
The names of the forty-eight men who attended the meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Waldorf were printed in the ''Motion Picture Herald'' and ''[[Variety (magazine)|Daily Variety]]'', the film industry's primary trade publications. The principal participants who formulated the Waldorf Statement included: *[[Louis B. Mayer]]: [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] *[[Harry Cohn]]: [[Columbia Pictures]] *[[Spyros Skouras]]: [[20th Century Fox]] *[[Nicholas Schenck]]: [[Loews Theatres]] *[[Barney Balaban]]: [[Paramount Pictures]] *[[Samuel Goldwyn]]: [[Samuel Goldwyn |Samuel Goldwyn Company]] *[[Albert Warner]]: [[Warner Bros.]] *[[William Goetz]]: [[Universal Studios|Universal-International]] *[[Eric Johnston]]: [[Association of Motion Picture Producers]] and [[Motion Picture Association of America]] *[[Mendel Silberberg]]: [[lawyer]] for [[Association of Motion Picture Producers]] *[[James F. Byrnes]]: former [[United States Secretary of State]] *[[Dore Schary]]: [[RKO Pictures]]
'''The Waldorf Statement:'''
"Members of the Association of Motion Picture Producers deplore the action of the 10 Hollywood men who have been cited for contempt by the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]]. We do not desire to prejudge their legal rights, but their actions have been a disservice to their employers and have impaired their usefulness to the industry.
We will forthwith discharge or suspend without compensation those in our employ, and we will not re-employ any of the 10 until such time as he is acquitted or has purged himself of contempt and declares under oath that he is not a [[Communist]].
On the broader issue of alleged subversive and disloyal elements in Hollywood, our members are likewise prepared to take positive action.
We will not knowingly employ a Communist or a member of any party or group which advocates the overthrow of the government of the [[United States]] by force or by any illegal or unconstitutional methods.
In pursuing this policy, we are not going to be swayed by hysteria or intimidation from any source. We are frank to recognize that such a policy involves danger and risks. There is the danger of hurting innocent people. There is the risk of creating an atmosphere of fear. Creative work at its best cannot be carried on in an atmosphere of fear. We will guard against this danger, this risk, this fear.
To this end we will invite the Hollywood talent guilds to work with us to eliminate any subversives: to protect the innocent; and to safeguard free speech and a free screen wherever threatened.
The absence of a national policy, established by Congress, with respect to the employment of Communists in private industry makes our task difficult. Ours is a nation of laws. We request Congress to enact legislation to assist American industry to rid itself of subversive, disloyal elements.
Nothing subversive or un-American has appeared on the screen, nor can any number of Hollywood investigations obscure the patriotic services of the 30,000 loyal Americans employed in Hollywood who have given our government invaluable aid to war and peace."

{{Infobox wrestling promotion |name = Women of Honor |image = |caption = |acronym = WOH |established = 2002; re-launched as unique brand in 2015 |folded = |style = [[Women's professional wrestling]] |location = [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]] |founder = |parent = [[Ring of Honor]] |sister = |formerly = |website = {{URL|http://www.rohwrestling.com}} }} '''Women of Honor''' is a term used by [[Ring of Honor]] (ROH) to refer to its [[Women's professional wrestling|female talent]]. The term is applied universally to [[professional wrestling|wrestlers]], backstage interviewers, and [[manager (professional wrestling)|managers/valets]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rohwrestling.com/news/view-future-women-honor |title=A View of the Future with the Women of Honor |publisher=ROH Wrestling |date= |accessdate=2016-04-15}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rohwrestling.com/product/women-honor-2-disc-set |title=The Women of Honor (2 Disc Set) |publisher=ROH Wrestling |date= |accessdate=2016-04-15}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestlinginc.com/wi/news/2015/0730/598853/ring-of-honor-adopting-women-division/ |title=Ring Of Honor Adopting Women's Division? |website=WrestlingInc.com |date=2015-07-30 |accessdate=2016-04-15}}{{cite web|url=http://wrestlingnews.co/major-update-on-ring-of-honor-creating-a-womens-division/ |title=Major update on Ring of Honor creating a women’s division - Wrestling News |website=Wrestlingnews.co |date=2015-08-06 |accessdate=2016-04-15}} ==Promotion== ROH had its first women's match on June 22, 2002 at its ''Road to the Title'' show. It saw [[Sumie Sakai]] defeat Simply Luscious. Women's wrestling in ROH had been sporadic since then. ROH featured female stars like [[Sara Del Rey]], [[Daizee Haze]], and others on shows, even releasing a DVD featuring Del Rey, Haze, [[Amazing Kong]], [[Mickie James]], [[MsChif]], [[Lacey (wrestler)|Lacey]], and others. Some of these matches were featured on ROH's television program on [[HDNet]] and, later, on its syndicated show, but ROH did not consistently brand women's matches as Women of Honor until 2015. The popularity of [[Women's professional wrestling|women]] in Ring of Honor has resulted in Ring of Honor taping a pilot for a standalone Women of Honor program.{{cite web|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/SquaredCircle/comments/44io9m/roh_taping_a_women_of_honor_pilot_at_tonights/|title=ROH taping a Women Of Honor pilot at tonight's tapings according to MLW|website=[[Reddit]]|date=February 6, 2016|accessdate=June 22, 2016}} Ring of Honor has also made numerous Women of Honor branded merchandise available for purchase.{{cite web|url=http://rohwrestling.com/catalog/apparel/women-honor|title=Women Of Honor apparel|website=ROH Wrestling|date=June 22, 2016|accessdate=June 22, 2016}} The pilot aired as a Women of Honor-branded television special the weekend of June 25, 2016 and its success led to a Women of Honor taping that is available on DVD.{{cite web|url=http://www.rohwrestling.com/ippv/my-ppv/7816-women-honor-baltimore-md-vod|title= 7/8/16 Women Of Honor - Baltimore, MD (VOD)|website=ROH Wrestling|date=July 9, 2016|accessdate=December 6, 2016}} Currently, Ring of Honor regularly airs and promotes Women of Honor matches on their [[YouTube]], [[Facebook]], and [[Twitter]] platforms. As of June 2018, the only two videos to receive 3 million or more views on Ring of Honor's YouTube page are Women of Honor matches, both featuring regular Women of Honor competitor, "The Gatekeeper" [[Kelly Klein]]. {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/user/ringofhonor/videos?view=0&shelf_id=5&sort=p|title=Popular Uploads|website=[[YouTube]]|date=December 6, 2016|accessdate=December 6, 2016}} Matches are called and presented by [[Ian Riccaboni]]. He has been joined by [[Taeler Hendrix]],{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oRbIb-NY_F0&t=1s|title=Women of Honor Wed - KELLY KLEIN vs MARY DOBSON #WoHWed (5/8/16 Chicago)|website=[[YouTube]]|date=June 1, 2016|accessdate=December 6, 2016}} [[Mandy Leon]],{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cekJAhsE7xA&t=336s|title=TAELER HENDRIX vs SUMIE SAKAI from Lowell, MA 10-1-16|website=[[YouTube]]|date=October 12, 2016|accessdate=December 6, 2016}} [[Veda Scott]],{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2M21Ro5KE18&list=PL53kKJBMWATcFGQFDJeUHiV_hWzHb6TJw&index=6|title=#WOHWed - Taeler Hendrix & Jessicka Havok vs. Mandy Leon & Deonna Purrazzo|website=[[YouTube]]|date=October 5, 2016|accessdate=December 6, 2016}} [[Matt Taven]] and [[B.J. Whitmer]]{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uQTzFeH4tzA&t=248s|title=Women of Honor Wednesday SOLO DARLING vs KELLY KLEIN #WoHWED|website=[[YouTube]]|date=February 10, 2016|accessdate=December 6, 2016}} for YouTube exclusives and [[Nigel McGuinness]] for the two Women of Honor television specials.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j1P50aDGNY0&t=269s&list=PL53kKJBMWATcFGQFDJeUHiV_hWzHb6TJw&index=2|title=Women of Honor Wednesday: Faye Jackson VS ODB - Nashville, TN|website=[[YouTube]]|date=November 16, 2016|accessdate=December 6, 2016}} In February 2017, ROH partnered with Japanese promotion [[World Wonder Ring Stardom]] for a Women of Honor tryout camp.{{cite web | url = http://www.rohwrestling.com/news/ring-honor-conducting-first-ever-women-honor-tryout-camp | title = Ring of Honor Conducting the First Ever Women of Honor Tryout Camp | date=February 16, 2017 | accessdate=February 16, 2017 | work=[[Ring of Honor]]}} ==Episodes== So far there have been three televised specials. ==Roster== [[file:Sumie Sakai.jpg|right|thumb|175px|[[Sumie Sakai]]]] {| class="wikitable" |- !Ring Name !Real Name !Nickname |- |[[Brandi Rhodes]] |Brandi Alexis Runnels | |- |[[Jenny Rose]] |Unknown | |- |[[Jessie Brooks]] | |“Bonesaw Jessie Brooks” |- |[[Karen Q]] |Karen Yu | |- |[[Kelly Klein]] |Kelly Klein |"The Gatekeeper"
